title: Determining the LSRL From Summary Statistics
question_text:
A nutritionist wanted to investigate the relationship between the number of fat grams ($x$) and the total number of calories ($y$) found in foods offered at fast-food restaurants. She randomly selected $16$ food items found at local fast food restaurants and gathered information about these food items from the nutritional information provided by the restaurants, Here are some statistics related to her findings:

If the correlation for the relationship between number of fat grams and total number of calories is $0.947$, what is the equation of the LSRL?
solution:
All of the formulas you need to complete this problem can be found in the reference materials provided with the AP exam. Of course, it is important to review these reference materials ahead of time so that you know what will be provided and understand what each of the formulas relate to.

We are attempting to write the equation of the LSRL. In the reference materials, this equation is given in the form:

$$\hat { y } ={ b }_{ 0 }+{ b }_{ 1 }x$$

The formula for the slope of the LSRL is given as follows:

$${ b }_{ 1 }=r\dfrac { { s }_{ y } }{ { s }_{ x } }$$

To use this formula, you will need to know that $r$ represents the correlation, ${ s }_{ y }$ represents the standard deviation of the $y$ values and ${ s }_{ x }$ represents the standard deviation of the $x$ values.

Fill in the formula:

$${ b }_{ 1 }=(0.947)\dfrac { 188.79 }{ 11.81 } =15.138$$

Now we can find the $y$-intercept of the LSRL. The formula given in the reference materials is:

$${ b }_{ 0 }=\overline { y } -{ b }_{ 1 }\overline { x } $$

Fill in the formula:

$${ b }_{ 0 }=441.875-(15.138)(20.875)=125.869$$

Now that we know both the slope and $y$-intercept, we can substitute these values into the form of the equation of the LSRL as follows:

$$\hat { y } ={ b }_{ 0 }+{ b }_{ 1 }x$$

$$\hat { y } =125.869+15.138x$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. This equation results from interchanging values related to $x$ with values related to $y$ when completing calculations.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. This equation results from making the same mistake as noted above for Choice 'A' and also reversing the slope and $y$-intercept in the equation.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because the values of the slope and $y$-intercept have been interchanged.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. We cannot simply use the average $y$-value ($\overline { y } $) as the value of the $y$-intercept, nor can we use the average $x$ value ($\overline { x } $) as the slope or coefficient of $x$ in the equation of the LSRL.
